data.text: For the new site use the online editor to add and edit links

On firstdoor.axion5.com there is now at the very bottom a login link. Click on it, and authenticate using your andrea@firstdoor.com.au address. You will have to set a password. 

After login you should see a box under the greendoor with your email address. 

Click on a text and a editing toolbar should appear. Edit the text and a blue save button appears on the left. Click the save button to make your changes permanent.

If you want to logout, look for the link at the very bottom again. 

You can also edit the events side bar by the way.

Don't worry if something goes wrong, I'm making automated daily backups and can restore anything very easily.

I disabled the sync. So any changes you make in dbeditor will not sync with the new site anymore.

data.text:
What dropbox account have you synced on your computer? It's not firstdoortraining@gmail.com is it? 

I've put all documents in a dropbox folder on the firstdoortraining@gmail.com account. I can share the folder with the dropbox account you're using on your computer and you can add and remove documents yourself. 

To add a link to a file in dropbox:
First retrieve the link:
See https://www.dropbox.com/help/167/en

You should have a copied link now.

In dbeditor.axion5.net open a text to edit, highlight the text you want to change in to a link and either in the click on the menu Insert then Insert link, or type Control-K

Paste the link to the dropbox file into the url box, and set the target.

That should be it.

data.text:
The following applies to the site served of the new server:  http://firstdoor.axion5.net .

Added xml site map for bots and html map for humans (see very bottom of page. The one for humans is for bots as well really. No more hashes and bangs means google can crawl the site properly. The site is able to respond to a bot with a static page (non-javascript) page, but so far the crawler tests I've had google do retrieve the full page, even better. 

The site is serving properly compressed and minified resources, properly cached on the server and then again  behind a content delivery network (clouldflare), which means I get very few requests through to the actual server, which is good. Depending on how often you want to update the site, I can reduce the load even more. 

The site is up for testing at firstdoor.axion5.net I went through it carefully, but I probably missed things. And things still can go wrong. So if you can test it as well then after a couple of weeks I can make it go live and replace the current site.

I will then submit the site map to all search engines. Search engine optimization will depend on google being able to crawl the site properly, which it will. The second thing is to have other sites link to firstdoor.com.au. That's what google really relies on for ranking. Have you submitted firstdoor already as a business to google places? So it shows up on google maps?

Attached is a report. Site is getting scores of over 90/100. I can still optimize some images, and serve part of the resources from a different domain, the rest is the sharethis buttons and google analytics, out of my hands. 

Both the test site and the real one are running on my own Linode server. I would like to sign you up with somewhere else then nodejitsu, updating the site on there takes ages, fails now and then, and I can't get at the backend. Prices are from about $10/month, Linode is $20/month, but has a lot of support for the developer,, now I know what I am doing a bit, I can set it up somewhere cheaper if you'd prefer that.

data.text:
Fixed the issue for IE8 and IE9. Turns out the browser went into quirks mode because I had added a comment on the first line of the page. So no more comment on the first line and it works again.
 
Support and usage of IE7 is dropping across  the web, and the site doesn't really work  in IE7, I wouldn't know how to get it working anyway, since there are no developer tools in the browser, but I think I already sent you an email about that.

So if a site is not coming out properly, check first if it they are using IE7, came out in 2006, worldwide usage is under 1%, so not very likely they are still using IE7, but if they do suggest they upgrade.

IE8 and IE9 and IE10 should work properly.

Anyway, sorry for the hiccup, another lesson learned, I should always keep testing in IE, no matter how small the change apparently. I made the change somewhere this week, so the site should  have been working fine till then in IE.

I am leaving this site as is for now, and use another site to test out changes, once we're both happy with the change I will update the live site.

data.text: You don't need to sign out of dropbox. I mean the dropbox application you got running on your computer, the app that lets you access your dropbox folder on your own computer, in windows explorer. If you access dropbox in your browser via dropbox.com, then you will need to sign out, but only to authenticate and connect in dbeditor.axion5.net, after that you can sign into dropbox again using the dropbox.com web page. This is unrelated to the dropbox app on your computer, that is the little dropbox icon in your tray. Hope this helps. Or you can use a separate browser, for instance firefox to access dbeditor,  then you can leave your regular browser logged into the dropbox.com website. Again all of this does not affect your dropbox folder syncing with your other dropbox account.
